summary: This is a Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General (OIG) memorandum providing a status update on the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) implementation of recommendations from a June 2023 OIG report concerning the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. It details the BOP's responses to eight specific recommendations aimed at improving suicide prevention protocols, inmate monitoring, staffing, and security camera systems.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center prompted the original OIG investigation and the subsequent recommendations this memorandum addresses.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General issued its final report investigating the Federal Bureau of Prisons' custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Automated Staffing Tool Implementation
events.description: The BOP's Automated Staffing Tool (AST) went live for all BOP professions to aid in workforce planning and addressing staffing shortages.

events.title: Security Camera Monthly Reporting Effective
events.description: A new mandatory monthly Security Camera Report process for all BOP facilities became effective to ensure camera functionality and accountability.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's June 2023 report made eight recommendations to the BOP regarding Epstein's custody; one was previously closed, and the remaining seven are currently 'Resolved' based on BOP's reported actions.

The BOP is revising multiple Program Statements (internal policies) to implement new protocols for inmate cellmate assignment after suicide watch, monitoring of high-risk inmates, visit approvals, inmate whereabouts accounting, and security camera functionality checks.

A key BOP response to staffing shortages (Recommendation 6) includes implementing an Automated Staffing Tool, analyzing recruitment/retention incentives, using nationwide Direct Hire Authority, and pursuing special salary rates for correctional officers and nurses.

A new mandatory monthly reporting process for security camera systems at all BOP facilities was implemented on June 1, 2024, requiring detailed functionality checks and reporting to regional directors.
The OIG states it will consider closing each 'Resolved' recommendation only after the BOP finalizes the cited policy guidance and provides it to the OIG for review, indicating ongoing oversight.
